conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light from a source, projecting its outline onto a surface.
The position and size of a shadow depend on the height of the light source and the angle of the light rays relative to the object.

premise: The position and size of a shadow depend on the height of the light source and the angle of the light rays relative to the object.
conclusion: As the light source moves upward, the angle of the light rays becomes steeper, causing the shadows to move closer to the base of the objects.

conclusion: When the light source moves upward, the shadows become smaller because the light rays are more vertical and less spread out.
Object A (Apple) casts a circular shadow. Its shadow is relatively small and close to the object.
Object B (White cloth) casts a rectangular shadow. Its shadow is larger and more spread out compared to the apple.
Object C (Transparent object) casts a faint shadow due to its translucent nature. Its shadow is elongated and diffused.
Object D (Chicken leg) casts an irregular shadow. Its shadow is elongated and slightly larger than the object itself.
